a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 13 4 + nCr 13 9 = 1430"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9}$. The final Answer is 1430
 ### Proof
 Note that $\dbinom{13}{4} = \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} = \dbinom{13}{9}$.
 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\
 &= 2\times 13\times 1\times 11\times 5 \\ &= 13\times 11\times 10 \\ &= \boxed{1430}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 13 4 + nCr 13 9 = 1430"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find the sum of the binomial coefficients "13 choose 4" and "13 choose 9". The final answer is 1430.

 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\
 &= 2\times 13\times 1\times 11\times 5 \\ &= 13\times 11\times 10 \\ &= \boxed{1430}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n k. nCr n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"

 proof-

 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\

theorem
fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda>n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 13 4 + nCr 13 9 = 1430"
 proof-

 ### Proof
 Note that $\dbinom{13}{4} = \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} = \dbinom{13}{9}$.
 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\
 &= 2\times 13\times 1\times 11\times 5 \\ &= 13\times 11\times 10 \\ &= \boxed{1430}. \end{align}

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. choose n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "choose 13 4 + choose 13 9 = 1430"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9}$. The final Answer is 1430
 ### Proof
 Note that $\dbinom{13}{4} = \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} = \dbinom{13}{9}$.
 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\
 &= 2\times 13\times 1\times 11\times 5 \\ &= 13\times 11\times 10 \\ &= \boxed{1430}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes choose :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n k. choose n k = fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k))"
shows  "choose 13 4 + choose 13 9 = 1430"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In combinatorics, the number of ways to choose $k$ elements from a set of $n$ elements is denoted as $\binom{n}{k}$, which can be calculated using the formula $\binom{n}{k} = \frac{n!}{k!(n-k)!}$. Find the value of $\binom{13}{4} + \binom{13}{9}$. The final answer is $1430$.

assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda> n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 13 4 + nCr 13 9 = 1430"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9}$. The final Answer is 1430
 ### Proof
 Note that $\dbinom{13}{4} = \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} = \dbinom{13}{9}$.
 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\
 &= 2\times 13\times 1\times 11\times 5 \\ &= 13\times 11\times 10 \\ &= \boxed{1430}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes nCr :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "nCr = (\<lambda> n k. fact n div (fact k * fact (n - k)))"
shows  "nCr 13 4 + nCr 13 9 = 1430"
 proof-

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n r :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13"
and h1 : "r = 4"
and h2 : "\<forall> n r. binomial n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
shows  "binomial n r + binomial n (n - r) = 1430"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Compute $\dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9}$. The final Answer is 1430
 ### Proof
 Note that $\dbinom{13}{4} = \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} = \dbinom{13}{9}$.
 Thus, we have \begin{align} \dbinom{13}{4}+\dbinom{13}{9} &= 2\times \dbinom{13}{4} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13!}{4!9!} \\ &= 2\times \dfrac{13\times 12\times 11\times 10}{4\times 3\times 2\times 1} \\ &= 2\times 13 \times \dfrac{12}{4\times 3} \times 11 \times \dfrac{10}{2\times 1} \\
 &= 2\times 13\times 1\times 11\times 5 \\ &= 13\times 11\times 10 \\ &= \boxed{1430}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes n r :: nat
assumes h0 : "n = 13"
and h1 : "r = 4"
and h2 : "\<forall> n r. binomial n r = fact n div (fact r * fact (n - r))"
shows  "binomial n r + binomial n (n - r) = 1430"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a set of 13 items, find the sum of the number of ways to choose 4 items and the number of ways to choose the remaining 9 items. The final answer is 1430.
